The political orientations of Republican and Democratic voters have shifted from 2008 to 2016. In 2008, 59% of Republican voters wanted their party's leaders to work with Obama, while 36% wanted them to "stand up" to the new president. In 2016, 60% of Republican voters wanted their party to move in a more conservative direction, while 36% wanted a more moderate direction. In 2008, 57% of Democratic voters wanted their party's leaders to move in a more moderate direction, while in 2016, 49% wanted a more liberal direction and 47% wanted a more moderate direction. From July to December 2015, perceptions of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS showed a significant shift in public opinion. In July, 36% of respondents believed the campaign would definitely or probably fail, while 55% thought it would definitely or probably succeed. By December, the percentage of those who believed the campaign would fail dropped to 27%, and the percentage of those who believed it would succeed rose to 66%. Perceptions about the relationship between Islam and violence have not changed significantly since last year, though these opinions, already politically polarized, have become even more so. Currently, 46% say the Islamic religion is more likely than others to encourage violence among its believers; about as many (45%) say the Islamic religion does not encourage violence more than other religions. The share of the public saying that Islam is more likely than other religions to encourage violence has dropped four percentage points since a historical high of 50% in September 2014. For much of the past decade, public views on this measure have been closely divided. The partisan divide over whether Islam encourages violence is now as wide as it has ever been. Fully 68% of Republicans say Islam encourages violence more than other religions, a historical high but little changed since last fall. By contrast, just 30% of Democrats say Islam is more likely to encourage violence than other religions, down from 42% in September 2014, but on par with Democratic opinion at other points in recent years. The share of liberals saying Islam is more likely to encourage violence is down 14 points since the fall of 2014. About two-thirds (68%) of Republicans say Islam is more likely to encourage violence, little changed from September 2014 (67%), but the highest share saying this on a question that dates to 2002. In contrast, the share of Democrats associating Islam with violence has declined 12 percentage points since last year, from 42% to 30%. Ideological divides are even starker, and growing: About three-quarters (77%) of conservative Republicans say that Islam is more likely to encourage violence than other religions (just 16% say it does not). Liberal Democratic opinion is nearly the inverse: 73% of liberal Democrats say Islam is no more likely to encourage violence than other religions. Seven-in-ten white evangelical Protestants say Islam encourages violence more than other religions, the highest percentage of any religious group and little changed from 2014. By comparison, about half of Catholics (49%) and white mainline Protestants (51%) say this. Just 32% of those ages 18 to 29 say Islam encourages violence to a greater degree than other faiths, compared with roughly half of those in other age groups. Americans generally express more worry than enthusiasm when asked about automation technologies. Most prominently, they are roughly twice as likely to express worry (72%) than enthusiasm (33%) about a future in which robots and computers are capable of doing many jobs that are currently done by humans. They are also around three times as likely to express worry (67%) than enthusiasm (22%) about algorithms that can make hiring decisions without any human involvement. By comparison, public views towards driverless vehicles and robot caregivers exhibit more balance between worry and enthusiasm. A majority of Americans are broadly familiar with the notion that automation may impact a wide range of human employment, and most consider the concept to be generally realistic. Fully 85% of the public has heard or read about this concept before, with 24% indicating they have heard or read “a lot” about it. A roughly comparable share (77%) thinks this idea is at least somewhat realistic, and one-in-five indicate that the concept seems extremely realistic to them. One-in-five Americans find the concept of machines doing most human jobs in the future to be extremely realistic. For the most part, Americans consider this scenario to be plausible; express more worry than enthusiasm about the prospect of machines performing many human jobs; and anticipate more negative than positive outcomes from this development. They strongly favor the notion that machines might be limited to jobs that are dangerous or unhealthy for humans, and they offer somewhat more measured support for other types of interventions to limit the impact of widespread automation, such as the enactment of a universal basic income or national service program for displaced workers. And although they view certain jobs as being more at risk than others, a significant majority of today’s workers express little concern that their own jobs or careers might be performed by machines in their lifetimes. Beyond the examples noted above, Americans anticipate significant changes to the nature of jobs and work in the coming decades as a result of automation. Overall, roughly three-quarters of Americans (77%) think it’s realistic that robots and computers might one day be able to do many of the jobs currently done by humans, with 20% describing this prospect as extremely realistic. And substantial shares of Americans anticipate that automation will impact a number of specific career fields over the course of their lifetimes. Sizable majorities expect that jobs such as fast food workers and insurance claims processors will be impacted by automation. The public is divided on whether or not there should be limits placed on how many jobs businesses can automate, with 58% feeling there should be limits and 41% believing businesses are justified in replacing humans with machines if they can receive better work at a lower cost. There is strong support for limiting machines to performing dangerous or unhealthy jobs, with 85% of Americans in favor. Additionally, 60% of Americans support providing all Americans with a guaranteed income to meet their basic needs, and 58% support a national service program that would pay humans to perform jobs even if machines could do them faster or cheaper. The majority of Americans, regardless of party affiliation, support limiting machines to performing dangerous and dirty jobs. However, there are significant differences in support for a universal basic income and a national service program between Democrats and Republicans. Most Americans rate K-12 STEM education as average or worse compared with other developed nations, so, too, do those with an advanced degree in STEM. While most Americans give positive ratings for how well the K-12 public schools teach reading, writing and mathematics, public assessments of STEM education for U.S. students in grades K-12 are middling. A large majority of Americans say such education is no better than average compared with other developed nations. Views of higher education in science, technology, engineering and math are a bit more positive, but there, too, only a minority of the public considers U.S. STEM education to be at least above average compared with other industrialized nations. In contrast, just 13% of those with a STEM postgraduate degree rate K-12 STEM education as above average and about half (51%) say the U.S. is below average in this regard. The influence of 'Social media/bloggers' on Arab youth increased from 2013 to 2014. This indicates a growing recognition of the role that social media and bloggers play in shaping the perspectives and attitudes of Arab youth. The levels of confidence and likelihood are evaluated based on the type, amount, quality, strength, and consistency of evidence and the degree of expert agreement on the finding. Confidence is expressed qualitatively and ranges from low confidence (inconclusive evidence or disagreement among experts) to very high confidence (strong evidence and high consensus). Likelihood statements have a specific probability associated with them, ranging from very unlikely (less than or equal to a 1 in 10 chance of the outcome occurring) to very likely (greater than or equal to a 9 in 10 chance). The author teams determined the appropriate level of confidence or likelihood by assessing the available literature, determining the quality and quantity of available evidence, and evaluating the level of agreement across different studies. For specific descriptions of the process by which each chapter author team came to consensus on the Key Findings and assessment of confidence and likelihood, see the Traceable Account section for each chapter. Perceptions of political parties' ethics and extremism vary significantly among different educational and political affiliation groups. Among those with at least a college degree, 31% say "high ethical standards" does not describe either the GOP or the Democratic Party, while 43% say it describes one and not the other, and 17% think it describes both. This contrasts with the views of those with less education, where 49% say "high ethical standards" describes one party and not the other, and 26% say it describes neither party. Additionally, among Republicans and Republican leaners, 66% describe their party as having high ethical standards, while 64% of Democrats and Democratic leaners say the same about their party. However, 48% of the public view the Republican Party as "too extreme," compared to 42% who view the Democratic Party as too extreme. Views on Trump's handling of economic policy and perceptions of his ethical standards vary significantly among different political groups. According to the data, a majority of the public expresses at least some confidence in Trump's ability to make good decisions about economic policy, with 53% expressing confidence and 46% expressing little or no confidence. However, there are deep partisan divisions on these measures, with 75% of Republicans giving the administration high marks on ethical standards, while 86% of Democrats rate its ethical standards negatively. This indicates that while there is some level of confidence in Trump's economic policy decisions, there is a stark contrast in the perception of his ethical standards between Republicans and Democrats. The data also shows that conservative Republicans are more likely to express positive views of the ethical standards of Trump administration officials, with only 15% expressing negative views, compared to 36% of moderate and liberal Republicans. This further highlights the partisan divide in perceptions of Trump's ethical standards. In summary, while there is some level of confidence in Trump's economic policy decisions, there is a significant partisan divide in the perception of his ethical standards, with Republicans generally expressing more positive views and Democrats expressing more negative views. The opinions among Republicans and Democrats regarding Trump's conduct and the ethical standards of his administration have shown significant differences and changes over time. According to the data:

- **Republicans and Republican Leaners**:
  - In May 2018, 38% of Republicans and Republican leaners said they like the way Trump conducts himself as president, while 45% had mixed feelings and 16% did not like it. This indicates a slight shift from August 2017, where 30% liked his conduct, 38% had mixed feelings, and 31% did not like it.
  - Conservative Republicans are more likely to like Trump's conduct (44%) compared to moderate or liberal Republicans (25%).
  - In terms of ethical standards, 15% of conservative Republicans express negative views, while about a third (36%) of moderate and liberal Republicans say the ethical standards are not good or poor.

- **Democrats and Democratic Leaners**:
  - Democrats remain deeply critical of Trump's conduct, with 85% saying they do not like the way Trump conducts himself in office. This is consistent with previous data, showing little change since August.
  - Among Democrats, there are modest differences along ideological lines, with 8% of conservative or moderate Democrats and 93% of liberal Democrats giving low marks for the ethical standards of the Trump administration.

- **Overall Public Opinion**:
  - The public's evaluation of Trump's handling of his job as president has been little changed in recent months and is roughly on par with ratings at the outset of his presidency.
  - The ethical standards of top Trump administration officials are rated as excellent (9%) or good (30%) by about four-in-ten Americans, while 58% say they are not good (21%) or poor (36%). This is lower than ratings for other administrations dating back to Ronald Reagan's administration in 1983.

- **Approval and Disapproval**:
  - The approval and disapproval ratings for Trump show that 54% disapprove of his job performance, with 42% strongly disapproving and 27% not strongly disapproving. Approval ratings are 39%, with 33% strongly approving and 26% not strongly approving.
  - There are significant differences in approval and disapproval based on demographic factors such as age, race, and education level.

- **Handling Specific Issues**

Voter perceptions of political entities and campaign negativity in the 2016 election are closely related. The 2016 presidential campaign was viewed as extraordinarily negative, with 92% of voters saying there was more mudslinging or negative campaigning than in past elections, which is 20 percentage points higher than the previous high after the 2004 election. This negative perception extended to the way the winning candidate, the parties, the press, and the pollsters conducted themselves during the campaign, with post-election evaluations being far more negative than after any election dating back to 1988. Both political parties received their lowest grades ever for their conduct during the campaign, with only about a quarter giving an A or B to the Republican Party (22%) and the Democratic Party (26%). Similarly, voters gave abysmal grades to the press and pollsters, with just 22% giving the press a grade of an A or B, while 38% gave it a failing grade. Pollsters received even lower grades, with fewer voters awarding grades of A or B (21%) than a grade of F (30%). Public perceptions of government efforts to combat terrorism have shifted significantly over time, with a notable decline in positive ratings since the start of the year. Initially, 72% of Americans rated the government's efforts as very or fairly well, but this has dropped to 46%, with 52% now saying the government is doing not too well or not at all well. This change is more pronounced among Republicans, with a sharp decline from 59% to 18% in positive ratings. Democrats remain the only group where a majority (64%) still rate the government's efforts positively, though this is down from 85%. Independents' positive ratings have also dropped by 25 points, from 69% to 44%. The shift in concern over government policies is more pronounced among Republicans, with 71% now saying their greater concern is that anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough, up from 57% in January and 38% in July 2013. This concern is also shared by a majority of Democrats (54%), though the shift has been less pronounced. The perception of government efforts to combat terrorism also varies by age, with older adults (50 and older) more likely to give the government low marks (57% say it is not doing well) compared to younger adults (18-29 years old), where 46% give a negative rating and 53% say it is doing very or fairly well. Perceptions of terrorism and government efforts to combat terrorism have undergone significant changes over time, with notable differences among various demographic and political groups. Initially, the share of the public mentioning economic issues as the most important problem was higher, but this has decreased, with terrorism now being cited by nearly three-in-ten Americans as the most important problem, marking the highest level since February 2003. This shift is particularly pronounced among Republicans, with 41% mentioning terrorism, defense issues, and national security or ISIS, compared to 28% of independents and 23% of Democrats.

Evaluations of the government's job in reducing the threat of terrorism have become more negative across the political spectrum. Democrats are now the only partisan group in which a majority (64%) say the government is doing at least fairly well, down from 85% in January. Independents' positive ratings have dropped 25 points, from 69% to 44%, and just 27% of Republicans now say the government is doing very or fairly well reducing the terrorist threat, down from 63% at the beginning of the year.

Older and less educated Americans are more likely to give the government low marks for its efforts to reduce the threat of terrorism. For instance, 57% of those 50 and older say the government is not doing well, compared to 46% of younger adults (18-29 years old) who give the government a negative rating. Additionally, 58% of those with a postgraduate degree rate the government's performance positively, compared to 48% of those with a bachelor's degree and 44% of those with less education.

There is also a significant partisan divide in perceptions of terrorism and government efforts. Republicans are more likely to view the government's efforts negatively, with 72% saying the government is not doing well, compared to 34% of Democrats. Independent voters, including those who lean towards a party, have distinct views on government regulation and economic fairness compared to Democrats and Republicans. According to the data:

American perceptions of China's role in handling COVID-19 and broader U.S.-China relations have evolved significantly, with a notable increase in negative views. According to a Pew Research Center survey, 73% of U.S. adults now have an unfavorable view of China, up 26 percentage points since 2018. This souring sentiment is largely attributed to the belief that China mishandled the initial outbreak and subsequent spread of COVID-19, with 64% of Americans saying China has done a bad job dealing with the pandemic. Additionally, 78% of Americans place a great deal or fair amount of blame on the Chinese government's initial handling of the COVID-19 outbreak in Wuhan for the global spread of the virus. 

In terms of economic ties, around 68% of Americans say current economic ties between the U.S. and China are in bad shape, up 15 percentage points since May 2019. This decline in economic relations is accompanied by a growing sense that China is an enemy of the United States, with 26% of Americans describing China as such. The partisan divide is also evident, with Republicans and Republican-leaning independents significantly more likely than Democrats and Democratic leaners to have a very unfavorable view of China and to criticize the Chinese government's role in the global pandemic. 

Furthermore, 50% of Americans think the U.S. should hold China responsible for its role in the outbreak of the coronavirus, even if it means worsening economic relations, while 38% think the U.S. should prioritize strong U.S.-China relations, even if it means overlooking any role China played in the outbreak. This indicates a shift towards a tougher stance on China, with 73% of Republicans and Republican leaners supporting holding China responsible for the pandemic, compared to 37% of Democrats and Democratic leaners. 

Overall, the data suggests a growing perception of China as a threat, both in terms of its handling of the COVID-19 pandemic and its broader impact on U.S. interests. This has led to a decline in economic ties and a more adversarial stance towards China, particularly among Republicans.

In the U.S., political affiliation significantly influences preferences for foreign policy partners. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to name Israel as a top foreign policy partner (26%) compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (9%). Democrats place more emphasis on Canada and Mexico. However, views of Germany are similar among partisans in the U.S., with both sides ranking Germany fifth on the list of most or second-most important foreign policy partners. In Germany, there is less dramatic partisan difference, with supporters of the CDU/CSU, SPD, and Greens naming France as the first or second-most important partner, followed by the U.S. 

When it comes to cooperation with other countries, there is a divergence between American and German views. Nearly seven-in-ten Americans (69%) want to cooperate more with Germany, compared with only half of Germans who say the same about the U.S. However, the percentage of Germans who want to cooperate more with the U.S. has increased nine points since 2018. 

In terms of cooperation with Russia, Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to want greater collaboration. Increased cooperation with Russia is more common among Republicans in the U.S. (41%) than Democrats (32%), as well as among Germans living in former East Germany (75%) than in the former West (63%). 

Democrats in the U.S. are more likely to want greater cooperation with Germany than Republicans. In Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU are more willing to want greater cooperation with the U.S. than those who support the Greens and the SPD. This aligns with data on the international image of the U.S., where those on the ideological right in Germany tend to be more favorable toward the U.S. overall. 

In summary, political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany influence preferences for foreign policy partners and desired cooperation levels, with Republicans in the U.S. showing a stronger preference for Israel and increased cooperation with Russia, while Democrats lean more towards Canada and Mexico. In Germany, there is a general consensus among different political stripes on the importance of France and the U.S., but a significant difference in the desire for cooperation with Russia between East and West Germans.

Americans and Germans have differing opinions on military intervention and defense spending. In the U.S., a majority of Americans believe it is sometimes necessary to use military force to maintain order in the world, with about eight-in-ten holding this view, while only about half of Germans agree. Additionally, Americans are more likely to see the use of force as justified, with nine-in-ten American conservatives and about six-in-ten German adults on the right sharing this view. However, fewer Americans see a need for European allies to increase national defense spending, whereas Germans are divided on the issue. The U.S. public is also more supportive of increased defense spending in Europe, with Republicans and Republican-leaning independents being more likely to favor this than Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents. In contrast, Germans are not as convinced about the importance of U.S. military bases for their country's national security, with about half seeing them as important and 45% disagreeing. These differences are also reflected in the views of the EU, with roughly seven-in-ten Germans favoring the union compared to only about half of Americans. Furthermore, Americans and Germans take opposing views on whether their country should defend NATO allies against Russia, with six-in-ten Americans saying their country should defend a NATO ally in the event of a potential Russian attack, while an equal share of Germans say their country should not. These differences in opinion are also evident in the views of different age groups and political parties in both countries. For example, younger Americans are more likely to see the use of force as justified, while older Germans are more likely to view it as necessary. Similarly, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents in the U.S. are more likely to favor increased defense spending in Europe, while the Greens in Germany are less likely to support it. This shift is more pronounced among Republicans, whose support for increased defense spending by allies has fallen by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019. In contrast, Germans are divided on whether to increase or maintain current levels of defense spending, with about 40% in favor of increasing spending and 41% wanting to keep it the same. From 2017 to 2019, American and German views on national defense spending have undergone significant changes. In the U.S., there has been a notable shift in opinion regarding European allies' defense spending. In 2017, 45% of Americans believed that their European allies should increase their defense budgets, but by 2019, this number had dropped to 35%. The percentage of Americans who think spending should remain the same has increased from 37% in 2017 to 50% in 2019. This indicates a growing sentiment in the U.S. that the current level of defense spending by European allies is sufficient.

In Germany, the public's views on defense spending have also changed. In 2017, 32% of Germans supported increasing their country's defense spending, while 51% wanted to maintain the current level. By 2019, the percentage of Germans in favor of increasing defense spending had risen to 40%, and those wanting to keep spending the same had decreased to 41%. This suggests a slight but significant shift towards supporting increased defense spending in Germany.

Partisan differences within these countries are also evident. In the U.S., Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to favor increased defense spending in Europe compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents. However, there has been a decline in the share of Republicans who think the U.S.'s European allies should increase their defense budgets, falling by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019. Democrats have also seen a more modest decline in this view.

In Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU are on balance in favor of defense spending increases, with 51% supporting this view. Members of the SPD fall in the middle, with 41% saying Germany should increase defense spending. In contrast, supporters of the Greens express more skepticism, with only 28% saying they want to raise defense spending. This highlights the partisan divide within Germany on the issue of defense spending.

Overall, the evolution of views on national defense spending in both the U.S. and Germany reflects a complex interplay of changing public opinion and partisan differences. While there is a growing sentiment in the U.S. that current defense spending levels by European allies are sufficient, Germany is seeing a slight shift towards supporting increased defense spending. The predictions about the global influence of the U.S. and China after the coronavirus outbreak vary significantly among different demographic and political groups. According to the data, there is a clear partisan divide on the question of how the U.S.'s international influence will be affected by the pandemic. Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S.'s international influence will be strengthened as a result of the crisis, while Democrats are about four times more likely than Republicans to expect American influence to weaken after the outbreak. There is also internal division among Democrats on this question, with liberal party supporters 20 percentage points more likely than conservatives and moderates within the party to foresee the decline of U.S. international influence.

In terms of age, older Americans and Republicans are also especially likely to say they have a negative opinion of China. When asked about China's influence on the world stage, half of Americans believe it will decline after the coronavirus outbreak, while nearly one-in-five think Chinese influence will grow, and about a third think its global standing will be about the same. There is a large partisan divide on this question: roughly six-in-ten Republicans believe China's international clout will diminish as a result of the coronavirus outbreak, while just 40% of Democrats say the same. Age divides also emerge on this question, with American adults ages 65 and older being 16 percentage points more likely than those under 30 to say China will have less global influence after the crisis.

Education is also tied to views about how the pandemic will shape America's role in international affairs. In general, Americans who have completed higher levels of education are more likely to think the country's global influence will recede. From 2008 to 2015, financial optimism among different Hispanic subgroups has increased significantly. For instance, the share of Latinos who expect their family’s financial situation to improve has risen by 14 percentage points, from 67% in 2008 to 81% in 2015. This is a faster increase than in the general population, where the share rose by only 6 percentage points, from 61% in 2008 to 67% in 2015. The optimism has grown roughly twice as fast among Latinos who had completed some college (20 percentage points) compared to those with a high school diploma or less education (9 percentage points). The optimism is also higher among younger and middle-aged Hispanics, with nine-in-ten Hispanic adults under the age of 30 expecting their financial condition to get better, a 13-point rise. The gains in economic optimism are similarly large among Latinos ages 30 to 49 and 50 to 64 (16 points for each group). From 2000 to 2015, the perceptions of financial well-being among Latinos have shown a significant improvement, with a notable rise in optimism about their family's financial future. In 2000, only 31% of Latinos expected their family's finances to improve, which increased to 43% by 2015. This trend is reflected in the image1, which shows a steady increase in the percentage of Latinos expecting financial improvement over the years. Additionally, the unemployment rate for Latinos has decreased from a high of 12.8% in 2010 to 6.4% in 2015, as depicted in image7. This decline in unemployment aligns with the growing confidence in financial well-being, indicating a positive shift in economic conditions for the Latino community during this period. The data from image8 further supports this trend, showing a significant increase in the percentage of Latinos expecting their family's finances to improve from 23% in 2008 to 40% in 2015. This comprehensive analysis highlights the positive economic outlook and improved financial perceptions among Latinos from 2000 to 2015.

The trends in unemployment rates and economic perceptions between Hispanic and non-Hispanic populations show distinct differences. According to the data, the Hispanic unemployment rate has improved since the Great Recession, falling from a high of 12.8% in 2010 to 6.4% in 2015, but it remains above its low of 5% in 2006 and higher than that for non-Hispanic workers. This indicates a slower recovery in employment for Hispanics compared to non-Hispanics. 

Economic perceptions among Hispanics have become more positive over time, with 72% expecting their children to be better off financially than they themselves are now, compared to 31% in 2004. This optimism contrasts with the general public's view, which has become less positive since 2004. Despite this optimism, the median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession, remaining at $42,491 in 2014, and the Hispanic poverty rate is 23.6%, higher than pre-recession levels. 

The data also shows that Hispanic households experienced the largest percentage decline in their net worth through 2009 of any major racial or ethnic group, and unlike white households, their net worth continued to fall after the recession. This suggests that Hispanics have faced greater economic challenges and have not fully recovered from the recession, leading to persistent income and wealth disparities between Hispanic and non-Hispanic populations. 

In summary, while the Hispanic unemployment rate has improved, it remains higher than that of non-Hispanics, and economic perceptions are more positive among Hispanics. However, income and wealth disparities persist, with Hispanics experiencing a larger decline in net worth and higher poverty rates compared to non-Hispanics. 

![Hispanic unemployment rate has improved but remains higher than non-Hispanic workers](image8)
![Hispanics have more positive economic perceptions but face income and wealth disparities](image7)
Hispanic households have faced higher unemployment rates, lower median household incomes, higher poverty rates, and greater declines in net worth compared to all U.S. households from 2000 to 2015.

From 2008 to 2015, perceptions of personal financial situations among Latino groups have improved significantly. In 2008, only 23% of Latinos rated their personal finances as excellent or good, but by 2015, this figure had risen to 40%. This represents a 17 percentage point increase. In contrast, the share of all Americans with a similarly positive view of their finances remained essentially flat during the same period, with only a slight increase from 41% in 2008 to 43% in 2015. 

Regarding family income relative to the cost of living, in 2015, about half (53%) of Latinos said their family income was not keeping up with the cost of living, while 37% said their income was staying about even with the cost of living, and 10% said it was going up faster than the cost of living. This is similar to the views of blacks and whites on this issue. However, between 2014 and 2015, Hispanic views of family income in relation to the cost of living were unchanged, with about half of all Hispanic adults in both years saying they were falling behind financially, as was true for the U.S. public as a whole. 

Overall, the data suggests that while there have been improvements in perceptions of personal financial situations among Latino groups, concerns about family income relative to the cost of living remain significant. The improvements in personal financial perceptions are more pronounced among younger Latinos, with about half (48%) of Latinos ages 18 to 29 reporting that they were in excellent or good financial shape in 2015, a 27 percentage point increase from 2008. This is more than double the share who had a similarly positive view of their finances in 2008. 

In summary, while there have been notable improvements in perceptions of personal financial situations among Latino groups from 2008 to 2015, concerns about family income relative to the cost of living remain a significant issue. The improvements are more pronounced among younger Latinos, but the overall picture suggests that there is still a long way to go in terms of achieving financial stability and security for all Latino groups.

Internet usage and device ownership among seniors show distinct patterns compared to the general adult population. Seniors are less likely to go online initially, but once they do, they tend to make the internet a part of their daily routine. Among seniors who use the internet, 71% go online every day or almost every day, and an additional 11% go online three to five times per week. This frequency increases with the ownership of a smartphone or home broadband connection, with 78% of older broadband users and 84% of older smartphone owners going online daily or almost daily. 

Device ownership among seniors differs notably from the general population. While 77% of all adults own a cell phone, only 59% of seniors do. Similarly, 18% of all adults own a smartphone, compared to just 10% of seniors. The ownership of tablets or e-readers is also lower among seniors, with 27% owning one compared to 43% of all adults. 

The trends in daily internet usage among seniors are influenced by age, education, and income. Seniors aged 65-69 are more likely to go online daily (74%) compared to those aged 70-74 (68%) and 75-79 (47%). Education and income also play a significant role, with higher rates of daily internet usage observed among seniors with higher levels of education and income. 

In summary, while seniors are less likely to go online initially, those who do tend to make the internet a part of their daily routine. Device ownership among seniors is lower compared to the general population, with notable differences in cell phone, smartphone, and tablet/e-reader ownership. Age, education, and income are key factors influencing the daily internet usage patterns among seniors.

The device ownership among older adults differs notably from the general population in several specific ways. For instance, tablets and e-book readers are as popular as smartphones among older adults, with each being owned by 18% of them. However, smartphone ownership among older adults is only 18%, which is significantly lower than the 59% of older adults who use the internet. This suggests that while older adults are adopting certain devices, their overall internet usage is still relatively low compared to the general population. Additionally, the usage of social networking sites by older Americans has been steadily increasing, but it has not yet reached majority status. Among older adults who use the internet, 46% use social networking sites such as Facebook, which is well below the national average of 73% of adult internet users. This indicates that while older adults are becoming more connected, their usage patterns and preferences may differ from those of younger generations. Perceptions of fairness and effectiveness vary significantly across different automated systems used for decision-making. For instance, the personal finance score algorithm is viewed as effective by 54% of Americans but only fair by 32%, indicating a 22% difference. The perception of the response to the COVID-19 outbreak by public health officials and Donald Trump varies significantly between Democrats and Republicans, as indicated by multiple surveys from March to August. 

According to the text quotes:
- The share of Republicans who rate public health officials positively has fallen 31 points, from 84% to 53% (quote [2]).
- Democrats' views of public health officials are largely unchanged over that time period (74% in March, 72% today) (quote [2]).
- The share of Democrats who rate Trump’s response as “poor” has risen steeply since then. In March, 56% of Democrats said Trump’s response to the coronavirus was poor; today, 82% do so (quote [3]).
- Positive views of hospitals’ response to COVID-19 cross party lines; wider differences on other officials, Trump (quote [4]).
- Donald Trump gets lower ratings for his response to the outbreak than he did in March. Trump’s overall job approval also is lower than in March, though it is effectively unchanged since June (quote [5]).
- Democrats also are more likely than Republicans to give positive ratings to their state and local government officials for how they have responded to the coronavirus outbreak (quote [6]).
- There are much wider partisan differences in views of how public health officials, such as those with the CDC, are responding to the outbreak. Currently, 72% of Democrats and those who lean to the party say public health officials are doing well in (quote [7]).
- The public also is less positive about how public health officials are responding to the coronavirus, with virtually all of the decline in positive assessments coming among Republicans (quote [9]).
- This shift has come almost entirely among Republicans; only about half of Republicans (53%) give CDC officials and other public health officials positive ratings for their response to the outbreak, 31 points lower than in late March (84%). About seven-in-ten Democrats (72%) say public health officials have done an excellent or good job in responding to the coronavirus, little changed since March (74%) (quote [10]).
- Positive assessments of how state government officials and local government officials are responding to the outbreak also have slipped since March, by 14 points and 9 points, respectively. The declines in approval of state and local officials have been steeper among Republicans than among Democrats (quote [12]).

American perceptions of state government COVID-19 response and their views on Trump's handling of the pandemic show significant differences in terms of effectiveness and criticism. According to the data, a majority of Americans (69%) are concerned that state governments have been lifting restrictions too quickly, while only 30% believe they have been too slow to lift restrictions. This indicates a general dissatisfaction with the pace of reopening. In contrast, Trump's response to the pandemic has been met with more criticism, with nearly half of Americans (48%) rating his response as "poor," up from 32% in March. This suggests that Trump's handling of the pandemic is viewed more negatively than the state governments' response. Furthermore, the data shows that while 51% of Americans believe state and local governments have been more effective in handling the pandemic, only 22% believe the federal government has been more effective, with 87% of Democrats viewing the U.S. response as less effective compared to other wealthy countries. This highlights a significant partisan divide in perceptions of the federal government's response. Overall, these findings suggest that political affiliations play a significant role in shaping perceptions about the main reasons for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak.

The perspectives on the reasons for rising COVID-19 cases and the lifting of restrictions vary significantly across political affiliations. According to the data:

- **Republicans**: A majority of Republicans (62%) believe that the increase in confirmed coronavirus cases is primarily due to more people being tested, rather than more new infections. This view is more prevalent among conservative Republicans (68%) than moderate and liberal Republicans (53%). In contrast, only 36% of Republicans think the rise in cases is mainly because of more new infections. Republicans are also more divided on the lifting of restrictions, with 53% expressing concern that restrictions have not been lifted quickly enough, while 45% are more concerned that they have been lifted too quickly.

- **Democrats**: Democrats overwhelmingly attribute the rise in coronavirus cases primarily to more infections, not just more testing (80%). Democrats are more unified in their concern that restrictions have been lifted too quickly, with 90% of liberal Democrats and 88% of conservative and moderate Democrats expressing this view.

- **General Public**: Overall, 69% of Americans are more concerned that state governments have been lifting restrictions too quickly. This concern is higher among Black adults (84%) and Hispanic adults (72%) compared to white adults (65%).

- **Testing and Infections**: The general public is divided on whether the increase in confirmed cases is due to more testing or more new infections, with 60% attributing it to more testing and 39% to more new infections. However, this view is more prevalent among Republicans (62%) than Democrats (19%).

- **Economic Recovery**: There is a significant partisan divide on the best way to help the U.S. economy recover. Republicans are more likely to believe that significantly reducing coronavirus infections to a level where more people feel comfortable going to stores, schools, and other workplaces is the more effective way (53% among those living in counties where deaths resulting from COVID-19 have been higher). Democrats are more likely to believe that the primary reason confirmed coronavirus cases have increased is more new infections, not just more tests (77%).

- **Trust in Leaders**: Trust in leaders and institutions also varies by political affiliation. For instance, 87% of Democrats and 90% of Republicans trust hospitals and medical centers in their area, but only 37% of the public trusts Donald Trump to handle the coronavirus outbreak.

The differences in voting policy preferences related to requiring government-issued photo identification to vote are significant across different racial groups and political affiliations. According to the data, White Democrats are less supportive of this policy compared to Black, Hispanic, and Asian Democrats. Specifically, only 54% of White Democrats favor requiring voters to show government-issued photo identification, while larger shares of Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian Democrats (71%) support this policy. This indicates a notable disparity in preferences among Democrats of different racial backgrounds.

In contrast, Republicans show a strong preference for photo identification requirements, with 81% strongly favoring this policy compared to 30% of Democrats. This stark difference highlights the partisan divide on this issue. Furthermore, the data reveals that White Republicans are less supportive of policies aimed at easing voting compared to Hispanic Republicans. For instance, about half of Hispanic Republicans (51%) favor automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote, whereas only 35% of White Republicans support this policy.

The image data further supports these findings. Image 4 shows that 96% of White individuals, 65% of Black individuals, 72% of Hispanic individuals, and 71% of Asian individuals favor requiring government-issued photo identification to vote. This indicates that while a majority of all racial groups support this policy, there is a significant difference in the level of support among White individuals compared to other racial groups.

In summary, the preferences for requiring government-issued photo identification to vote vary significantly across different racial groups and political affiliations, with White Democrats being less supportive compared to other racial groups within the Democratic party, and Republicans showing a strong preference for this policy. Racial and ethnic differences significantly influence support for voting policies. This highlights a broader trend where White adults tend to be less supportive of policies aimed at increasing voting accessibility compared to other racial and ethnic groups.

The proposal for independent redistricting and early absentee voting options is viewed differently by various political and demographic groups. According to the data, nearly half of U.S. adults approve of a proposal by House Democrats that would require states to put together redistricting commissions composed of equal numbers of Democrats and Republicans to draw their congressional maps instead of having state legislatures come up with their own plans. However, there is a significant disparity in views on no-excuse absentee or early voting between Republicans and Democrats. While about half of Republicans who voted absentee or by mail favor no-excuse absentee or early voting, only about a third of early, in-person GOP voters and just 22% of those who voted in person on Election Day say the same. Among Democrats, there are only slight differences in these views between those who voted absentee and those who voted in person. Black adults are more likely than White, Hispanic, and Asian adults to favor 'no excuse' early, absentee voting. Additionally, there is a sizable disparity between how Republicans and Democrats voted in the presidential election, with roughly a third of Republican and Republican-leaning voters saying they voted absentee or by mail, compared with 58% of Democratic and Democratic leaners. The share of Republicans who say any voter should be allowed to vote early or absentee without a documented reason has fallen 19 percentage points, while Democrats and Democratic leaners are far more supportive of automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote and no-excuse early voting. Partisanship remains the most important factor in Americans' attitudes about this question, with only 38% of Republicans in favor of allowing all voters to vote early or absentee. White Democrats are more supportive of allowing all voters to vote early or absentee than are Democrats of other races and ethnicities, while the reverse is true for White Republicans compared with Hispanic Republicans. Democrats, on the other hand, have remained consistently supportive, with 84% favoring 'no excuse' early or absentee voting in 2021. Regarding automatic voter registration, in 2018, 49% of Republicans favored this policy, while in 2021, this number had dropped to 38%. Democrats have consistently supported automatic voter registration, with 82% in favor in 2021. From 2019 to 2022, Latino voters have shown a consistent preference for the Democratic Party, with 64% identifying as or leaning towards Democrats in 2022, compared to 62% in 2019. The Republican Party's support among Latino voters has remained relatively stable at around 30%. The economy has consistently been the top issue for Latino voters, with 80% considering it very important in 2022, up from 74% in 2019. Abortion has risen in importance, especially after the Supreme Court's decision to end the federal guarantee of a right to legal abortion, with 57% of Hispanic voters considering it very important in 2022, up from 42% in March. Demographic factors such as religious affiliation and political leanings significantly influence preferences, with Catholics and those with no religious affiliation showing higher support for the Democratic Party, and Evangelical Protestants showing higher support for the Republican Party. The strength of Hispanic identity is also linked to voting preferences, with those who strongly identify as Hispanic more likely to vote for the Democratic candidate. The views of Latino voters have been a focal point in the 2022 midterm elections, with their party affiliations and key issues being closely monitored.

Hispanic Democrats and Republicans have starkly different views on the future political role of Trump and the perception of racial discrimination. According to the data:

- **Future Political Role of Trump:**
  - **Hispanic Democrats:** A clear majority (94%) of Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners say they would not like to see Trump remain a national political figure. Only 4% of them think he should run for president in 2024.
  - **Hispanic Republicans:** In contrast, 63% of Hispanic Republicans and GOP leaners say they would like to see Trump remain a national political figure, with 41% of them believing he should run for president in 2024.

- **Perception of Racial Discrimination:**
  - **Hispanic Democrats:** Nearly three-quarters (73%) of Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners say people not seeing racial discrimination where it really does exist is a bigger problem.
  - **Hispanic Republicans:** About six-in-ten (62%) Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners say it is a bigger problem that people see racial discrimination where it really does not exist.

These differences highlight the deep partisan divide among Hispanics on these issues. The data suggests that Hispanic Democrats are more likely to view Trump negatively and to be concerned about the under-recognition of racial discrimination, while Hispanic Republicans are more supportive of Trump and more likely to believe that racial discrimination is often perceived where it does not exist.

Hispanic perceptions of socialism and capitalism vary significantly by political affiliation and age groups. According to the Center's survey, a larger share of Hispanics have a negative impression of socialism (53%) compared to a positive one (41%). However, Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners are split on their views of socialism, with 48% having a positive view and 48% having a negative view. In contrast, Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners have a more negative impression of socialism, with nearly three-quarters (72%) viewing it negatively.

When it comes to capitalism, Hispanics have a more positive than negative view, with 54% having a positive impression and 41% having a negative one. Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners are more likely to have a positive view of capitalism (68%) compared to Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners (50%).

By age groups, Latinos ages 18 to 29 are more evenly divided in their views of socialism, with 46% having a positive view and 50% having a negative view. This pattern is similar among all U.S. young people. In contrast, Latinos ages 50 to 64 and those 65 or older are more likely to have a negative view of socialism.

In summary, Hispanic perceptions of socialism and capitalism differ by political affiliation and age groups, with younger Hispanics and Hispanic Democrats being more divided in their views of socialism, while Hispanic Republicans and older Hispanics are more likely to have a negative view of socialism and a positive view of capitalism. Perceptions of political parties' efforts to earn Latino votes vary significantly among different demographic groups. For instance, a majority of Latino adults express positive views of the Democratic Party, with 71% saying it works hard for Latinos' votes, compared to 45% for the Republican Party. Among specific groups, immigrants, Spanish speakers, Catholics, and evangelicals are more likely to say Democrats work hard to earn their votes. However, only about a quarter of these groups feel the same about Republicans. This suggests a political landscape where the Democratic Party is seen as more attentive to Latino interests, potentially influencing voting patterns and party loyalty within the Latino community. The data also indicates that while there is a significant share of Latinos who see a great deal of difference between the parties, fewer than half believe there is a major difference, reflecting a complex and nuanced political environment.

The perceptions of the Democratic and Republican parties' efforts to engage with Latino voters differ significantly among different political affiliations. According to the data, a higher percentage of Latino registered voters identify with or lean toward the Democratic Party (64%) compared to the Republican Party (33%). This trend has been relatively stable over recent years, with little change in party affiliation among Latinos.

The Democratic Party is perceived to work harder to earn Latino votes, with 71% of Latino registered voters agreeing with this statement, compared to 45% of those who identify with or lean toward the Republican Party. Similarly, 63% of Latino registered voters believe the Democratic Party really cares about Latinos, while only 34% of those who identify with or lean toward the Republican Party share this view.

In terms of the Republican Party's efforts, 45% of Latino registered voters believe the party works hard to earn Latino votes, and 34% believe the party really cares about Latinos. These perceptions are lower compared to the Democratic Party's efforts.

The data also shows that 60% of Latino registered voters believe the Democratic Party represents the interests of people like them, while only 34% of those who identify with or lean toward the Republican Party share this view. This indicates a stronger alignment between the Democratic Party and the interests of Latino voters.

Overall, the perceptions of the Democratic and Republican parties' efforts to engage with Latino voters differ significantly, with the Democratic Party being viewed more favorably in terms of working hard to earn Latino votes, caring about Latinos, and representing their interests. These perceptions have been reflected in the party affiliation trends, with a higher percentage of Latino registered voters identifying with or leaning toward the Democratic Party.

Perceptions of party differences and support for political parties among Hispanics show nuanced variations over time and by political affiliation. According to the 2022 National Survey of Latinos by Pew Research Center, a majority of Latino adults express positive views of the Democratic Party, with 71% saying it works hard for Latinos' votes, 63% believing it "really cares about Latinos," and 60% stating it represents the interests of people like themselves. In contrast, fewer Latinos hold similar views about the Republican Party, though a somewhat greater share (45%) say the GOP "works hard to earn the votes of Latinos." 

The survey also indicates that Latino registered voters identify with or lean toward the Democratic Party over the Republican Party by a nearly two-to-one margin (64% vs. 33%). This trend has been consistent over the past few years, as noted in the text. However, there is a notable uncertainty in future party affiliation among Latino registered voters, with substantial shares falling into groups with soft ties to the political parties.

In terms of perceptions of party differences, about half of Hispanics do not see a great deal of difference between what the Democratic and Republican parties stand for, with 36% saying there is a fair amount of difference and 16% saying there is hardly any difference at all between the parties. This perception is relatively consistent among both Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners (47%) and Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners (48%).

Among Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners, 47% see a great deal of difference, while 37% see a fair amount of difference and 15% see hardly any difference at all. Among Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners, 48% see a great deal of difference, 37% see a fair amount of difference, and 14% see hardly any difference at all.

The public has a very positive view of STEM jobs, with 71% believing they offer better compensation than other industries and 58% considering them to attract the brightest, most qualified young people. Additionally, women in STEM jobs are more concerned about diversity and discrimination in the workplace, especially those in computer jobs and majority-male workplaces. The data suggests that while there is a general consensus on the higher pay and prestige of STEM jobs, there are differences in how men and women perceive job characteristics and workplace equity. Men and women in STEM jobs value different job characteristics, with men placing more importance on opportunities for promotion and high-paying jobs, while women prioritize jobs that help others and are welcoming for people like them. These differences in values may contribute to the challenges women face in entering the STEM workforce, as they may be more likely to seek out jobs that align with their values, which may not always be available in STEM fields. Additionally, women may face discrimination and a lack of encouragement to pursue STEM from an early age, which can further hinder their ability to enter the workforce. The public image of STEM jobs as offering higher pay and more opportunities for advancement may also contribute to the perception that STEM is a male-dominated field, which can discourage women from pursuing these careers. Roughly 30% of STEM workers have earned a master's, doctorate, or professional degree, far exceeding the 12% of non-STEM workers with advanced degrees. The share of STEM workers with a bachelor's degree (but no postgraduate degree) is 36%, compared with 21% of non-STEM workers. Among STEM workers, life scientists are the most highly educated on average, with 54% having an advanced degree. STEM jobs have relatively high earnings compared with many non-STEM jobs, and the earnings gap persists even after controlling for educational attainment. Among workers with similar education, STEM workers earn significantly more, on average, than non-STEM workers. The wage gap between STEM and non-STEM workers has been widening since 1990. The wage gap between STEM and non-STEM workers persists even when controlling for educational attainment. Women comprise 47% of all employed adults today, up modestly from 45% in 1990, and they make up half of all employed adults in STEM jobs in the U.S. The share of women in STEM overall is driven in large part by women's overrepresentation in health-related jobs, the largest STEM occupational cluster. Three-quarters of healthcare practitioners and technicians are women. Racial and ethnic diversity in STEM is also varied. Black and Hispanic workers remain underrepresented overall; these groups are also underrepresented among those in STEM jobs with professional or doctoral degrees. Asians are overrepresented across all STEM occupational clusters and have an especially large presence in the college-educated STEM workforce, particularly in computer occupations, relative to their share among employed college graduates overall. Although women have made gains in representation in the STEM workforce over the past roughly 25 years, particularly in life and physical science jobs, they remain strongly underrepresented in some STEM job clusters, notably computer jobs and engineering. The self-identification of Hispanics in the U.S. across different generations is influenced by several factors, including mixed backgrounds, limited contact with Hispanic relatives, and few Hispanic cultural links. According to the text, 27% of adults with Hispanic ancestry who do not self-identify as Hispanic say they have never considered themselves Hispanic or Latino due to mixed Hispanic and non-Hispanic backgrounds or distant Hispanic ancestry. Another 16% say they do not consider themselves Hispanic despite their Hispanic ancestry because of their upbringing or limited contact with Hispanic relatives, while 15% say they do not speak Spanish or have no link to Hispanic culture. Additionally, 12% say they do not look Hispanic or identify as another race, and 9% were born in the U.S. and consider themselves American.

The image data supports these findings. For example, image1 shows that among self-identified Hispanics, 71% do not speak Spanish, and 84% do not have a Spanish last name. This suggests that language and last name are not significant factors in self-identification for many Hispanics. Image2 indicates that 53% of self-identified Hispanics often identify as Hispanic, while 25% sometimes do, 11% rarely do, and 10% never do. This suggests that self-identification as Hispanic is not always a consistent or strong identity for some individuals.

Image3 provides further insight into the factors influencing self-identification. Image5 indicates that 50% of self-identified Hispanics identify as Hispanic/Latino, while 23% identify as American.

The experiences of attending cultural celebrations and parental pride discussions differ significantly among generations of self-identified Hispanics and non-Hispanics. For self-identified Hispanics, the likelihood of attending Hispanic cultural celebrations decreases with each generation. Among immigrant self-identified Hispanics, 59% report that their parents often took them to such celebrations, while this drops to 49% for second-generation and 35% for third or higher generation. Similarly, the percentage of self-identified Hispanics whose parents talked often about their pride in their country of origin roots decreases from 57% for immigrants to 33% for the third generation. In contrast, among self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry, only 9% report that their parents took them to Latino cultural celebrations, and 60% say this never happened. This indicates a significant decline in cultural engagement and parental pride discussions as one moves further from the immigrant generation. The data suggests that the connection to Hispanic culture and identity fades across generations, with the third generation showing a marked decrease in both attending cultural celebrations and parental pride discussions. The connection to Hispanic heritage and language proficiency among self-identified Hispanics varies significantly across generations. According to the Pew Research Center's 2015 National Survey of Latinos, foreign-born Hispanics are most likely to speak Spanish and feel connected to their country of origin. Among foreign-born Hispanics, 61% are Spanish dominant, meaning they are more proficient in Spanish than in English, and 82% feel very or somewhat connected to their country of origin. In contrast, only 6% of second-generation Hispanics are Spanish dominant, and this number drops to essentially none among third-generation Hispanics. Similarly, the share of Hispanics who feel connected to their country of origin decreases from 82% among immigrants to 69% among the second generation and 44% among the third generation. This decline in Spanish use and connection to ancestral origins is consistent with the broader trend of assimilation and integration into American society across generations. The data also shows that while there is widespread support for the continued use of Spanish among future generations of Hispanics, the actual proficiency in Spanish declines sharply with each successive generation. This suggests that while the desire to maintain cultural ties remains strong, the practical ability to do so through language use diminishes over time. The differences in language proficiency and cultural connection across generations highlight the complex dynamics of identity and heritage in the Hispanic community in the United States.

The language dominance and sense of connection to Hispanic heritage among self-identified Hispanics vary significantly across different generations. According to the data:

1. **Language Dominance**:
   - **Foreign Born**: Among foreign-born Hispanics, 61% are Spanish dominant, 32% are bilingual, and only 7% are English dominant. This indicates a strong preference for Spanish among the first generation.
   - **Second Generation**: The second generation shows a shift towards bilingualism, with 51% being bilingual, 43% English dominant, and only 6% Spanish dominant.
   - **Third or Higher Generation**: By the third generation, the majority (75%) are English dominant, 24% are bilingual, and essentially none are Spanish dominant.

2. **Sense of Connection to Hispanic Heritage**:
   - **Foreign Born**: 82% of foreign-born Hispanics feel very or somewhat connected to their country of origin.
   - **Second Generation**: This connection declines to 69% among the second generation.
   - **Third or Higher Generation**: The connection further decreases to 44% among the third or higher generation.

These trends suggest that as the immigrant roots become more distant, the language dominance shifts from Spanish to English, and the sense of connection to Hispanic heritage diminishes across generations. This is supported by the data showing that while 82% of foreign-born Hispanics feel connected to their country of origin, this number drops to 44% by the third generation. Similarly, the prevalence of Spanish dominance decreases from 61% in the foreign-born group to essentially none in the third or higher generation, while English dominance increases from 7% to 75% over the same period. 

In summary, the language and cultural ties to Hispanic heritage weaken as the generations move further from their immigrant roots. This is evident from the increasing English dominance and decreasing Spanish dominance, as well as the declining sense of connection to the country of origin across generations.

The perceptions of connection to Hispanic heritage and the perceived advantages of being Hispanic vary significantly across different generations of self-identified Hispanics. According to the data, foreign-born Hispanics feel the strongest connection to their country of origin, with 82% feeling very or somewhat connected. This connection declines with each subsequent generation, with 69% of second-generation Hispanics and only 44% of third or higher generation Hispanics feeling the same level of connection. 

In terms of the perceived advantages of being Hispanic, the data shows that second-generation Hispanics are most likely to see their Hispanic background as an advantage, with 52% saying it has been an advantage in their lives. This is in contrast to 28% of immigrant Hispanics and 24% of third or higher generation Hispanics who feel the same way. 

These trends suggest that as Hispanic individuals move further away from their immigrant roots, their connection to their country of origin and the perceived advantages of being Hispanic tend to diminish. This is likely due to a variety of factors, including increased assimilation into American culture and a decrease in direct exposure to Hispanic traditions and customs. 

Overall, the data highlights the complex and evolving nature of Hispanic identity in the United States, with different generations experiencing and perceiving their heritage in distinct ways.

Connections to Hispanic heritage and perceived advantages vary significantly across generations among self-identified Hispanics. According to the data, foreign-born Hispanics feel the strongest connection to their family's country of origin, with 82% feeling very or somewhat connected. This connection decreases with each subsequent generation, with 69% of second-generation Hispanics and only 44% of third or higher generation Hispanics feeling the same level of connection [8]. 

In terms of perceived advantages, the second generation of Hispanics reports the highest impact of their Hispanic heritage on their lives, with 52% saying it has been an advantage. This is in contrast to immigrant Hispanics, where only 28% report the same, and third or higher generation Hispanics, where the percentage drops to 24% [7]. 

These trends suggest that as the distance from immigrant experiences increases, the sense of connection to the ancestral country and the perceived advantages of Hispanic heritage tend to diminish. This is further supported by the data showing that 70% of self-identified Hispanics feel that their Hispanic heritage has made a difference in their lives, with 34% feeling it has been an advantage, 56% feeling it has not made a difference, and 9% feeling it has been a disadvantage [10]. 

Overall, the data indicates that while Hispanic heritage can be a source of pride and advantage for some, especially in the second generation, its impact and perceived benefits tend to decrease with each subsequent generation. This is likely due to the increasing assimilation into American culture and the diminishing direct connection to the ancestral country. 

In conclusion, the connection to Hispanic heritage and the perceived advantages of being Hispanic vary significantly across generations, with the strongest connections and perceived advantages being reported by the second generation of Hispanics. This highlights the complex and evolving nature of Hispanic identity in the United States.

Perceptions of racial identity and the impact of Hispanic heritage vary significantly among generations of self-identified Hispanics in the U.S. According to the Pew Research Center surveys, the majority of self-identified Hispanics (69%) consider themselves Hispanic or Latino, with this percentage decreasing to 66% among the second generation and 46% among the third or higher generation. The share of self-identified Hispanics who say they are seen as Hispanic by passersby also decreases across generations, from 78% among foreign-born Hispanics to 46% among the third or higher generation. Experiences with discrimination related to being Hispanic are less frequent among higher generations, with 39% of self-identified Hispanics saying they have felt discriminated against because of their Hispanic or Latino background, compared to 7% of self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry. The composition of networks of friends also varies widely across immigrant generations, with 77% of immigrant Latinos saying all or most of their friends are Latinos, dropping to 55% among second-generation self-identified Latinos and 37% among third or higher generation self-identified Latinos. The language dominance also shifts across generations, with 75% of third or higher generation Hispanics being English dominant, compared to 61% of foreign-born Hispanics. Generational differences significantly impact the perception of discrimination and racial identification among Hispanics. According to the Pew Research Center's 2015 National Survey of Latinos, experiences with discrimination are less frequent among higher generations of adults with Hispanic ancestry. For instance, 39% of self-identified Hispanics say they have felt discriminated against because of their Hispanic or Latino background, with 42% of immigrant Latinos and 38% of second-generation Latinos reporting discrimination, while only 29% of third or higher generation Latinos report the same level of discrimination [2, 4]. This trend is also reflected in the perception of racial identification, with 78% of immigrant Latinos saying strangers on the street would think they were Hispanic or Latino, compared to 66% of second-generation Latinos and 46% of third or higher generation Latinos [6].

The surveys also show that the composition of networks of friends varies widely across immigrant generations. Most immigrant Latinos (77%) say all or most of their friends are Latinos, but this share drops to 55% among second-generation self-identified Latinos and only 37% among third or higher generation self-identified Latinos [11]. This indicates a shift in social networks and possibly in the perception of discrimination as generations progress.

Furthermore, the surveys reveal that the majority of non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry think others see them as white, with 59% of self-identified non-Hispanics saying they are seen as white [3]. This suggests a generational shift in racial identification and possibly in the experience of discrimination, as those who are seen as white may experience less discrimination than those who are seen as Hispanic.

In conclusion, generational differences impact the perception of discrimination and racial identification among Hispanics, with experiences of discrimination decreasing and perceptions of racial identification shifting as generations progress. Generational differences significantly impact the self-identification preferences and language use among Hispanics. According to the data, the use of the term "American" to describe oneself increases from 7% among immigrants to 56% among the third generation or higher, reflecting a stronger national identity as one moves further from their immigrant roots. This trend is mirrored in the decline of the use of country of origin terms. 

In terms of language, the percentage of Spanish-dominant Hispanics decreases dramatically from 61% among immigrants to 6% among the second generation and essentially none among the third generation. This indicates a shift towards English proficiency and away from Spanish as the primary language of communication.

The data also shows that the majority of Hispanics, regardless of generation, do not consider speaking Spanish a requirement for being Latino. This suggests that while language is a characteristic often linked to Latino identity, it is not a defining factor for many Hispanics.

In terms of identity, the data reveals that the share of Hispanics who consider themselves a typical American increases from 36% among immigrants to 73% among the third generation or higher. This reflects the birth country (the U.S.) and lifetime experiences of these generations.

Overall, the data indicates that as Hispanics move further from their immigrant roots, they tend to identify more strongly with their American identity and less with their Hispanic or Latino identity. This is reflected in their language use, self-identification preferences, and connection to their ancestral national origins.

The levels of concern about rising costs of living and unemployment vary between GCC and Non-GCC countries, revealing distinct regional differences in priorities. Employee access to Wi-Fi has a significant impact on customer loyalty and sales across different sectors.
